thread.title: What Trump advisers say about AT&T-Time Warner deal | Amazon wants to stream live sports | ‘Rogue One’ tracking for big debut - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: What Trump advisers say about AT&T-Time Warner deal | Amazon wants to stream live sports | ‘Rogue One’ tracking for big debut - MarketWatch

posts.author: Trey Williams
posts.title: What Trump advisers say about AT&T-Time Warner deal | Amazon wants to stream live sports | ‘Rogue One’ tracking for big debut - MarketWatch
posts.text:
Good afternoon, MarketWatch readers. Thanks for checking out this week’s edition of Swerve. Before we break for Thanksgiving, here’s your latest helping of news and musings on AT&T Inc. T, +2.19% Time Warner Inc. TWX, +0.84% and on what’s happening in the media industry as a whole. Plus, the latest news from President-elect Donald Trump. Sign up to receive Swerve: Time Warner, AT&T and the future of media .
Broken promises: President-elect Donald Trump made a lot of promises during his more than 18-month run to win the White House. He’s walked back several of those, including the scale of his planned border wall, the repeal and replacement of Obamacare and the plan to prosecute rival Hillary Clinton. Trump also promised he would straight up block AT&T’s proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner. His campaign said he “would never approve such a deal.” But as Recode reporter April Glaser writes , the advisers Trump tapped to oversee the FCC and Justice Department transitions “have a history of being very pro-industry and anti-regulation, particularly when it comes to mergers.”
Jeff Eisenach and Mark Jamison, who are helping with the FCC transition, argued in favor of AT&T’s proposed, but ultimately failed acquisition of T-Mobile in 2011. And Eisenach said consolidation was the best thing that could happen in the cable business when Comcast was considering a Time Warner takeover in 2013.
Angry bird: Donald Trump made sure the world knew his feelings about the “highly overrated” Broadway hit “Hamilton” and its cast ’s message to his Vice President Mike Pence last weekend. Trump took to Twitter again on Tuesday to vent about the New York Times. And not for the first time.
I cancelled today's meeting with the failing @nytimes when the terms and conditions of the meeting were changed at the last moment. Not nice
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 22, 2016 Trump met with — and gave an earful to — executives and anchors from the country’s five biggest TV networks on Monday, according to CNN Money . Trump reportedly vented about media coverage, but also committed to improving media access. On Tuesday he was set to meet with the New York Times, but canceled after incoming Chief of Staff Reince Priebus urged him to , according to Times reporter Sydney Ember. Priebus was allegedly concerned Trump would face questions he wasn’t prepared to answer. The meeting was eventually rescheduled. Times staffers posted updates throughout the duration of the meeting, which you can read here .
The dark side: Donald Trump’s new chief strategist Steve Bannon sat down with Michael Wolff of the Hollywood Reporter to talk about plotting “an entirely new political movement.” Bannon, who is the former news chief of controversial alt-right news site Breitbart, has been slammed since his appointment for being a white nationalist. He told Wolff:
“Darkness is good. Dick Cheney. Darth Vader. Satan. That’s power. It only helps us when they [liberals and the media] get it wrong. When they’re blind to who we are and what we’re doing.”
Amazon’s Hail Mary: Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +0.68% really wants to get into streaming sports. And any sport will do. Wall Street Journal reporter Shalini Ramachandran, citing sources, writes that Amazon has been in talks with the NBA, MLB, NFL and even lacrosse and surfing leagues for the rights to carry live games. Live sports are the last frontier in streaming TV, as one of the few things forcing fans to keep their cable TV subscription. The NFL and Twitter signed a deal to live stream Thursday Night Football games.
Team up: The two biggest fantasy sports sites, DraftKings Inc. and FanDuel Inc., have agreed to set aside their differences and merge, as they both struggle with regulatory and legal challenges to their core business, writes Wall Street Journal reporter Alexandra Berzon .
FOMO: Claire Atkinson at the New York Post reports that Walt Disney Co. DIS, +0.04% network ABC is exploring the possibility of a 24-hour news digital news channel.
Force to be reckoned with: Disney’s “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story,” set for its North American release on Dec. 16, is tracking for a massive $150 million box office debut, according to The Hollywood Reporter .
Thanks for reading Swerve. If you’re interested in keeping abreast of the AT&T-Time Warner deal and in keeping an eye on the future of media, sign up for the newsletter . For critical information before the markets open each morning, sign up for MarketWatch’s Need to Know , sent daily at 7:30 a.m. Eastern.
Follow Trey Williams on Twitter @Trey3Williams , and write to him at twilliams@marketwatch.com

Comment Amazon.com 
I am quite sure that many of us are already gearing up for Black Friday this year, as many retailers are kicking off their Black Friday deals this November 24th at 6 p.m. onward. After all, it is one of the rare times throughout the year where you will be able to enjoy relatively decent bargains on items that you might want. Amazon themselves are an exceptional electronic retailer, and have changed the fulfilment landscape to boot. This time around, it seems that Amazon wants Black Friday not only to be just a few days going all the way through to Cyber Monday, as they might be looking at an entire month of sales. 
Yes sir, you read that right -- a whole month of sales. Amazon started their 35 straight days of Black Friday deals from this week onward, allowing bargain hunters to obtain some of the stuff that they would like to have without having to break the bank -- at these deals will be long running, meaning they are around for a decent amount of time before Thanksgiving, going all the way after it. It seems that Amazon is working on releasing a new deal up to every five minutes, all the way until December 22nd. That would be three days before Christmas, and it ought to help you heave a sigh of relief knowing that there would still be opportunities to enjoy discounts on last minute purchases then to save your bacon. 
It is touted that some of the best deals available from Amazon will happen during the “Turkey Five” period, which happens to be the five days that fall between Thanksgiving and Cyber Monday. You can be sure that a huge range of this will be diversified , where some of them will end up as toys, while electronics ought to see a fair amount of action, not to mention opportunities to enhance your fashion wardrobe on the cheap. 
You will be able to check out the full list of Black Friday deals from Amazon over here . Feel free to play around with the settings as well as parameters, ranging from price to the percentage of discount. With millions of items available on Amazon, you would surely have plenty of choices to pick from, and the fact that customer reviews are there to help will go to some great lengths in making sure that you would be able to have an inkling of an idea on what you would be getting right before clicking on the "Purchase" button. 
Alternatively, you can also keep a keen eye out on Amazon's Cyber Monday deals through this particular page . Some of the other methods to keep tabs on the latest deals made available to the masses would be to being a regular on Today's Deals , where you can then keep track of the Deal of the Day and today's Lightning Deals. Alternatively, how about signing up for deals through daily emails , ensuring that you know what's tomorrow's Deal of the Day? Other methods include following social media accounts like Facebook in order to glean the most recent -- and more importantly, official piece of information.

thread.title: Striking pilots may crimp Amazon’s and DHL’s holiday package deliveries
thread.title_full: Striking pilots may crimp Amazon’s and DHL’s holiday package deliveries

posts.author: Bloomberg News
posts.title: Striking pilots may crimp Amazon’s and DHL’s holiday package deliveries
posts.text:
November 22, 2016, 12:35 PM Striking pilots may crimp Amazon’s and DHL’s holiday package deliveries By Bloomberg News ABX Air, the contractor for Amazon Air, will ask a judge to force striking pilots back to work. 
(Bloomberg)—ABX Air, which flies packages for Amazon.com Inc. and DHL Worldwide Express, plans to ask a judge to force striking pilots back to work and thwart a threat to disrupt deliveries during the holiday shopping season. 
About 250 pilots employed by ABX Air, a subsidiary of Air Transport Services Group Inc. , are striking to protest alleged staffing shortages at the cargo carrier. ABX Air operates 35 flights a day for Amazon, No. 1 in the Internet Retailer 2016 Top 500 Guide , and 45 daily flights for DHL, according to the Airline Professionals Association, Teamsters Local 1224, which represents the pilots. Some flights were grounded. 
The action comes as the retail industry gears up for its busiest period and shoppers increasingly shun bricks-and-mortar stores and shop from their phones and computers instead. Online spending in November and December will increase 11% this year to $91.6 billion, according to an October forecast from Adobe Systems Inc. 
“While they go through this court process, planes are not flying,” said Satish Jindel, president of SJ Consulting Group . “Obviously that is of concern to a company like DHL and Amazon.” But he said Amazon can shift some volume to United Parcel Service Inc. and FedEx Corp. and can also find some smaller contract parcel shippers to move packages if needed. 
The pilots are picketing outside ABX Air’s headquarters in Wilmington, Ohio, and DHL’s North American hub at Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport. 
The union says ABX Air is violating its contract by forcing pilots to work an excessive number of emergency assignments—preventing them from taking time off—because it doesn’t have enough pilots to meet the growing demands of companies like Amazon. The world’s biggest online retailer in March announced plans to lease 20 Boeing 767 freighters from ATSG to help it move inventory around the country. 
Amazon said in an emailed statement that it works with a variety of carriers and is confident in its ability to serve customers. DHL said by email that “due to a work stoppage affecting our airline partners, inbound deliveries to portions of the Americas will be delayed today.” 
Pilot strikes in the U.S. are rare due to the Railway Labor Act, a 90-year-old federal law intended to prevent labor disputes from disrupting commerce. And when strikes do occur they often don’t last very long because the company can ask a judge to intervene with a temporary restraining order until the court decides if the strike is legal. On rare occasions, if a dispute substantially threatens essential transportation in the country, the U.S. president could get involved. 
ATSG said it will seek a court order Tuesday to “restore the status quo operating environment,” while it continues discussions with union representatives. 
“Hopefully, sane minds will prevail and we’ll get things back to normal operations today,” said Quint Turner, chief financial officer for ABX parent ATSG. The company’s second airline, Air Transport International, is operating and will take steps to accommodate any extra demands caused by the pilot strike, he said. 
The pilots say their strike is allowed because of the contract violations, and voted to authorize a walkout in May. 
“For the past two years, we’ve been warning them that they are dangerously short on pilots,” said Rick Ziebarth, 59, who’s been with ABX for 39 years. “The lifestyle of our crews have really taken a nosedive. I can’t tell you how many birthdays, anniversaries and even funerals pilots can’t attend as a result of these emergency assignments.” 
Pilots on Amazon runs fly night and day from Wilmington to Dallas to Stockton, Calif., to Rockford, Ill., and back to Wilmington—sometimes with nowhere to rest but the cockpit, Ziebarth said. Such routes can increase fatigue because of rotations between night and day, he said. Pilots are willing to make accommodations for customers but want the company to abide by its contract by honoring vacation time and regulating emergency assignments, he said. 
Amazon’s air cargo operation is part of efforts to reduce its dependence on UPS and FedEx, as it expands a $99-a-year Prime membership service that can deliver orders in as little as a day. In addition to ATSG, Amazon in May entered into an agreement with Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc. to acquire and operate 20 Boeing Co. 767-300 freighters. 
A dedicated fleet helps Amazon shuffle inventory around the country more efficiently to meet demand spikes, while reducing the inventory it has to carry nationally. 
The ABX strike underscores how a national pilot shortage could hinder Amazon’s air cargo aspirations. Its logistics partners have to compete for pilots with UPS, FedEx and passenger carriers that pay better wages and offer better benefits. That’s a different game than filling warehouses with temporary workers because pilots require years of training, especially for big aircraft, said Matt Barton, an aviation industry economist with FlightPath Economics in Golden, Colo. 
“I don’t think Amazon has encountered a problem like the pilot shortage before and it doesn’t have a quick and easy solution,” Barton said. “A lot of these carriers are going to have a hard time finding the pilots they need." Topics

In addition to posting all the awesome Black Friday deals , just a reminder that we will also be hosting the fifth annual Black Friday Giveaway Extravaganza here on Hip2Save.com .
That’s right! Starting at 7AM MST on Black Friday, November 25th, I will randomly be selecting 4 Hip2Save readers, every hour, to win an Amazon Gift Card valued at $5, $10, $25, $50, $75 or even $100! We plan to give away OVER $2,000 worth of gift cards! 
Here’s how it will work: First, you must head over here and complete the giveaway form to be entered into Hip2Save’s Black Friday Giveaway Extravaganza .
Note that you only have through Thursday, November 24th, at 9:59PM MST to enter! Then, just be sure to check Hip2Save.com regularly on Black Friday, November 25th. Beginning at 7AM MST through 7PM MST, I’ll randomly select 4 entrants and will publish a post at the top of each hour identifying each of the 4 winners with their first name, last initial and a portion of their email address.
Each of the 4 winners will have exactly ONE hour to email bryn@hip2save.com to find out which Amazon Gift Card they have won. Note that you can only win once.
It should be lots of fun, so I hope you all will join me!

thread.title: Cargo pilot strike in Ohio may delay Amazon, DHL shipping
thread.title_full: Cargo pilot strike in Ohio may delay Amazon, DHL shipping

posts.title: Cargo pilot strike in Ohio may delay Amazon, DHL shipping
posts.text:
Employment and Internship Opportunities Cargo pilot strike in Ohio may delay Amazon, DHL shipping 
WILMINGTON, Ohio (AP) - Pilots for a cargo airline that carries packages for Amazon and DHL went on strike Tuesday, potentially causing delivery delays just as the holiday shopping season swings into high gear. 
The airline, ABX Air, said it would seek a court order to end the strike by about 250 pilots. 
The Teamsters union, which represents the pilots, said the strike had caused 75 flights to be canceled. ABX operates 35 daily flights for Amazon and 45 daily flights for DHL, according to the union. 
The pilots allege that ABX is understaffed and forces them to work on days off without giving them the compensatory time off that they are owed under their contract. 
The airline's president, John Starkovich, said the strike is illegal and that the dispute should be settled through arbitration. 
A spokesman for ABX parent company Air Transport Services Group Inc. said the company would not comment on the impact of the strike. 
Neither Amazon nor DHL responded immediately to requests for comment. 
Wilmington-based Air Transport Services earned $22 million in the first nine months of this year, down from $26.5 million in the same period of 2015. The company's labor costs have increased 30 percent in that time, according to a regulatory filing. 
The company's shares fell 24 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $16.44 on Tuesday. They have gained 86 percent in the past 12 months. Copyright 2016 The Associated Press.   This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
